page.title: 15THE RAILWAY IN OKEHAMPTON
page.content: Okehampton station was open in 1871 for the London and South Weatern Railway on its route to Plymouth. The opening was delayed by construction difficulties across the edge of the moor. (Perhaps the modern by-pass engineers should make note!) The railway became an important employer in the town until the decline in the 1960's and eventual closure in 1972. Today the station stands empty in its commanding position above the town. The line is still open to British Rail's Meldon Quarry 2km to the west. In April 1985 it was annouced that West Devon Council had arranged for trains to on four Saturdays in the summer. This would allow tourist to visit the town and shoppers time in Exeter. The first trip left Okehampton with 150 passengers and very few spare seats. A good start to a bold venture.
